uncertainties.Papilledema/Idiopathic intracranial hype: headache with visual disturbance (often bilateral) over weeks, risk factors include young obese women

steps.action: ASK PATIENT: What is your age and sex? Is the visual loss unilateral or bilateral, and did it start suddenly or gradually? Do you have eye pain or pain with eye movement, double vision, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, fever, or other constitutional symptoms? Any known medical history (eg, hypertension, autoimmune disease), current medications, and recent weight change?
steps.action_reason: Age/sex and laterality/onset of vision loss, presence of eye pain, and systemic symptoms strongly distinguish among optic neuritis, IIH/papilledema, compressive lesions, and temporal arteritis; medical history and weight help assess IIH and other risk factors.

steps.new_information: 69-year-old woman with gradual bilateral vision loss over 3 weeks, no eye pain, no systemic symptoms (no jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, fever, weight loss), history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia on treatment.

uncertainties.Giant cell arteritis (GCA): age fits and can cause subacute vision loss but lacks typical systemic/cranial symptoms
uncertainties.Compressive optic neuropathy (eg, pituit: gradual bilateral vision loss with potential visual field defects (bitemporal) and without pain
uncertainties.Non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic ne: common in older patients with vascular risk factors (HTN) but typically unilateral and sudden
uncertainties.Bilateral macular/retinal disease (eg, w: can cause progressive bilateral central vision loss in elderly without pain.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Ophthalmic exam (visual acuity, pupillary reactions including assessment for relative afferent pupillary defect, confrontation visual fields, dilated fundoscopic exam)
steps.action_reason: A focused ophthalmic exam can rapidly distinguish optic nerve pathology (optic disc swelling/atrophy, RAPD), retinal disease (macular changes, hemorrhages), and pattern of visual field loss (eg, bitemporal hemianopia suggesting chiasmal compression), which will narrow the differential between GCA, compressive lesions, ischemic optic neuropathy, and retinal disease.

steps.new_information: 69-year-old woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with 3 weeks of gradually worsening bilateral vision. Ophthalmic exam: OD 20/120, OS 20/80, normal pupils with no RAPD, full confrontation fields. Dilated fundus exam shows bilateral retinal hemorrhages and possible cotton wool spots suggestive of retinal vein occlusions; no optic disc edema or neovascularization.

uncertainties.Bilateral retinal vein occlusions (CRVO/: fundus hemorrhages and cotton wool spots fit, and HTN/hyperlipidemia are risk factors, but bilateral disease suggests systemic predisposition
uncertainties.Severe hypertensive retinopathy: can produce bilateral hemorrhages and cotton wool spots—need BP and arteriolar changes to distinguish
uncertainties.Hyperviscosity or hematologic disorder (: can cause bilateral retinal hemorrhages and vision loss—would explain bilateral involvement
uncertainties.Ischemic optic neuropathy/giant cell art: less likely given no disc edema or systemic symptoms, but age mandates consideration (check ESR/CRP)

steps.action_reason: Blood pressure will help differentiate hypertensive retinopathy versus retinal vein occlusion and assess severity (malignant hypertension could explain bilateral findings). Temperature and other vitals could raise concern for systemic/ inflammatory causes (eg, GCA) and influence urgency of further testing (ESR/CRP, labs). Vital signs are quick, noninvasive, and high-yield for narrowing the differential.

steps.new_information: Vital signs normal: Temperature 36.8°C, Blood Pressure 135/85 mmHg, Heart Rate 78 bpm, Respiratory Rate 16 breaths/min.

uncertainties.Bilateral central retinal vein occlusion: bilateral retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots suggest CRVO causing subacute bilateral vision loss
uncertainties.Bilateral branch retinal vein occlusions: fundus findings could reflect BRVO(s), though bilateral symmetric BRVO is less common
uncertainties.Systemic hyperviscosity or hematologic d: bilateral retinal vein occlusions raise concern for an underlying systemic cause
uncertainties.Ischemic optic neuropathy/giant cell art: less likely given absence of optic disc edema, RAPD, or systemic symptoms, but must be considered in an elderly patient.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) macula and fluorescein angiography (FFA) of both eyes
steps.action_reason: OCT will identify macular edema accounting for decreased visual acuity and guide ocular therapy; FFA will delineate the extent and pattern of retinal ischemia and help differentiate central vs branch vein occlusions and determine ischemic vs non-ischemic status, which informs urgency of treatment and need for systemic evaluation for hypercoagulable or hyperviscosity causes.

steps.new_information: OCT macula and fluorescein angiography (FFA) of both eyes are reported as normal despite bilateral fundoscopic findings of retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots.

uncertainties.Bilateral retinal vein occlusions (CRVO/: fundus hemorrhages and cotton wool spots with vision loss fit, but bilateral involvement is uncommon and OCT/FFA findings would often show macular edema/ischemia
uncertainties.Hypertensive retinopathy: longstanding hypertension can cause hemorrhages and cotton wool spots but BP is reasonably controlled and arteriolar changes were not specifically described
uncertainties.Hyperviscosity syndrome/hematologic mali: can cause bilateral retinal hemorrhages and visual decline with relatively normal OCT/FFA and would explain bilateral presentation
uncertainties.Diabetic retinopathy or other systemic v: possible if undiagnosed systemic disease but less likely given history.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: CBC with differential and peripheral smear
steps.action_reason: A CBC and peripheral smear can identify anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, abnormal circulating cells, or rouleaux formation/paraproteinemia clues that would support a hyperviscosity or hematologic cause for bilateral retinal hemorrhages and help distinguish this from isolated retinal vein occlusion or hypertensive retinopathy.

steps.new_information: CBC shows normal blood counts, peripheral smear with marked rouleaux formation suggesting increased circulating immunoglobulins.

uncertainties.Hyperviscosity syndrome from monoclonal: explains rouleaux and bilateral retinal vein occlusion-like hemorrhages
uncertainties.Bilateral central retinal vein occlusion: could cause retinal hemorrhages but bilateral simultaneous presentation is less likely
uncertainties.Cryoglobulinemia or other immune-complex: can cause vascular occlusion and elevated immunoglobulins but typically has systemic symptoms
uncertainties.Hypercoagulable state (eg, antiphospholi: can cause venous occlusions but does not explain rouleaux formation.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) with immunofixation, quantitative immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM), serum free light chains, and serum viscosity measurement
steps.action_reason: SPEP/immunofixation and free light chains will detect a monoclonal gammopathy (or polyclonal elevation) that would explain rouleaux; quantitative Igs clarify which immunoglobulin is elevated (Waldenström typically IgM, myeloma IgG/IgA). Serum viscosity testing will determine if hyperviscosity is present and could account for bilateral retinal venous stasis/hemorrhages, guiding urgent therapy (plasmapheresis) if positive.

steps.new_information: SPEP/immunofixation confirms a monoclonal IgM (likely kappa) with markedly elevated IgM level and elevated serum viscosity; peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation; clinical picture includes progressive bilateral visual decline with fundoscopic findings consistent with retinal venous congestion/hemorrhages.

uncertainties.Waldenström macroglobulinemia causing hy: explains IgM monoclonal spike, elevated viscosity, bilateral retinal changes and progressive visual loss
uncertainties.IgM MGUS coincident with bilateral centr: monoclonal gammopathy present but not causative
uncertainties.Cryoglobulinemia or immune-complex media: may be associated with IgM paraprotein
uncertainties.Hypercoagulable or thrombotic disorder c: less likely given systemic paraprotein and viscosity.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Urgent Hematology/Oncology consultation with recommendation for immediate therapeutic plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) and diagnostic workup (bone marrow biopsy, flow cytometry, cryoglobulins)
steps.action_reason: Therapeutic plasmapheresis is indicated urgently for symptomatic hyperviscosity (progressive vision loss, elevated serum viscosity) and can rapidly improve visual symptoms; hematology input and bone marrow studies are needed to distinguish Waldenström macroglobulinemia from IgM MGUS and to plan definitive therapy; cryoglobulins and flow cytometry will help evaluate alternative causes (cryoglobulinemia, lymphoproliferative disorder).

steps.new_information: Serum studies confirm a monoclonal IgM paraprotein (M-spike) with markedly elevated IgM and increased serum viscosity; hematology recommended urgent plasmapheresis and further diagnostic workup.

uncertainties.Cryoglobulinemia/immune complex-mediated: can be associated with monoclonal IgM and cause retinal vascular findings—cryoglobulins should be checked.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Bone marrow biopsy and aspiration with immunophenotyping/flow cytometry and cytogenetic studies
steps.action_reason: Bone marrow examination with immunophenotyping will distinguish Waldenström macroglobulinemia from IgM MGUS or other B‑cell/plasma cell neoplasms by quantifying marrow infiltration and characterizing the clonal cell type; results will guide urgent treatment decisions (confirm need for systemic therapy in addition to plasmapheresis).

steps.new_information: Bone marrow biopsy and aspiration with immunophenotyping/flow cytometry and cytogenetic studies: normal readings (no overt marrow infiltration detected).

uncertainties.Hyperviscosity syndrome due to monoclona: supported by elevated serum viscosity and retinal hemorrhages
uncertainties.Bilateral central retinal vein occlusion: less likely to explain bilateral subacute progression and rouleaux/IgM spike but remains in differential.

steps.action_reason: Patient has symptomatic hyperviscosity with progressive bilateral vision loss and markedly elevated serum viscosity due to monoclonal IgM. Immediate plasmapheresis both treats the emergent process (reduces IgM and viscosity to prevent irreversible visual loss and other complications) and is diagnostically informative (clinical improvement after exchange supports hyperviscosity as the driver). Bone marrow being "normal" does not obviate urgent therapy; marrow evaluation and further hematologic workup can continue in parallel.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Post-plasmapheresis serum viscosity and quantitative IgM level; cryoglobulin panel and cold agglutinin testing; repeat ophthalmic exam (visual acuity, pupillary reactions, dilated fundoscopic exam) and documentation of any change in visual symptoms.
steps.action_reason: Post-exchange viscosity and IgM will confirm whether plasmapheresis effectively reduced hyperviscosity (supporting hyperviscosity syndrome as cause). Cryoglobulins/cold agglutinins testing will evaluate alternative antibody-mediated vascular occlusion mechanisms. Repeat ophthalmic exam and symptom assessment will show clinical response and help correlate laboratory changes with ocular improvement, differentiating systemic vs primary ocular causes.

steps.action: ASK PATIENT: Since plasmapheresis and the interventions, has your vision improved, worsened, or stayed the same? Any new visual symptoms (flashes, floaters, pain) or systemic symptoms (bleeding, infections, fevers, weight loss)?
steps.action_reason: Patient-reported change in vision after plasmapheresis will help determine whether hyperviscosity was the primary reversible cause (expect improvement) versus permanent retinal ischemic damage or another ongoing process (no improvement). New systemic symptoms would suggest active hematologic disease requiring further workup.

steps.action_reason: Identifying a clonal lymphoplasmacytic process (eg, WM with MYD88 mutation) versus IgM MGUS will determine need for definitive systemic therapy (rituximab-based chemo) to prevent recurrent hyperviscosity and further retinal ischemic injury; peripheral blood/PET-CT help detect occult disease if marrow sampling was initially non-diagnostic.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: PET-CT (whole-body) to look for occult lymphadenopathy or organ involvement
steps.action_reason: A whole-body PET-CT can identify occult nodal or splenic disease or metabolically active lesions that would support a diagnosis of an underlying lymphoproliferative disorder/WM (vs MGUS or low-burden/undetected clone). Finding focal uptake would guide targeted biopsy; a negative PET-CT would make WM less likely and support MGUS or a very low-burden clone, prompting more sensitive molecular testing next.
